Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Heterogeneous Bubble Dynamics in Volcanic Conduits
Award.AbstractNarration:
Volcanic eruptions can have significant impact on life, infrastructure, commerce and climate. Erupting magma is a mixture of hot rock fragments (formerly magma), such as volcanic ash, and volcanic gases that are transported to surface as bubbles within the erupting magma. Bubbles may both, confine magmatic gases potentially resulting in large excess gas pressures, or they may facilitate syneruptive gas loss by forming permeable networks during bubble coalescence. Consequently, bubbles play a crucial role in a feedback with magma ascent rate and affect the style and explosive intensity of eruptions.

This project will further our quantitative understanding of the various processes that affect bubbles and magmatic gases during volcanic eruptions. We will develop a new bubble-scale numerical model for bubble growth, deformation and coalescence. The model will be calibrated to laboratory experiments that are specifically designed to facilitate the integration of empirical data. The bubble-scale model will then be coupled with a multiphase conduit flow model to address problems such as (1) the spatiotemporal evolution of gas pressure in an erupting magma with a polydisperse bubble size distribution; (2) the implications for magma fragmentation; (3) bubble coalescence during shear deformation of the erupting magma; (4) open-system gas loss by permeable flow through coalesced bubbles; and (5) shear localization within the ascending magma.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcome Report for NSF 1250441: Heterogeneous Bubble Dynamics in Volcanic Conduits

The goal of the proposed activity was to develop and use new bubble dynamics models to better constrain the physics of volcanic eruptions. Gas bubbles provide the driving force for eruptions, and have a fundamental impact on the dynamical behavior of volcanic activity and also on the chemistry of volcanic gases released during eruptions. In that context, the studies developed under the funding provided with this grant can be roughly decomposed into two types of contributions:

(A) the development of new experiments and numerical models to study bubble interactions in magmas. We focused on experiments geared to provide the physical insight into and useful parameterizations for bubble coalescence under two regimes: (1) gravity-driven and (2) capillary-driven drainage (Chinh et al., 2013). In parallel we developed the first bubble dynamics model that allows bubbles to interact, deform and coalesce (Huber et al., 2014) and used the experimental study for coalescence to build a coherent numerical framework where bubbles can deform and coalesce. The model allowed us to also study the behavior (growth rate) of bubbles undergoing Ostwald ripening and the deformation of a collection of bubbles under shear. Ostwald ripening is an interesting example where the key is to understand how bubbles with different sizes interact. That study prompted us to investigate the mechanics of deformation of bubble suspensions with different bubble sizes and lead a manuscript (Faroughi and Huber, 2015) published in Physical Review E.

(B) the second track that we pursued was to understand how bubbles trapped in volcanic product can provide information about the dynamics of the ascending magma in the volcanic conduit. Published approaches that relate volcanic deposits to conduit dynamics generally rely on several assumptions, most importantly that the ascent rate of magmas to the surface is constant (averaged). The ascent rate of magmas to the surface during an eruption is far from constant, because magmas degass as they approach the surface. On this account, we studied whether it is possible to go beyond the constant ascent rate assumption and invert complex non-linear decompression pathways from volatile kinetics in and around gas bubbles. We focused on the H2O-CO2 system, where the diffusion kinetics are different (slower for CO2) and the solubility of each phases depends non-linearly on the concentration of both phases in the bubbles. We conducted over a thousand numerical calculations of magma ascent during eruption under a range of conditions (decompression path, duration of the ascent, composition of the gas) and found that it is possible to constrain more than the average decompression rate from the diffusion profile of CO2 and H2O around bubbles. This study will be submitted for publication shortly and we are currently working with external collaborators to design laboratory experiments to test some of our findings and later apply them to well studied silicic eruptions.

Eventhough the grant that allowed us to conduct these studies has run out, we are working towards implementing these useful novel aspects of bubble growth and coupled gas kinetics into a multiphase continuum model for eruption dynamics (conduit flow). The goal will be to test the most critical parameters (shear localization because of heterogeneous bubble population versus, deformation and growth of bubbles) that control the eruption style and the potential for the magma to fragment during ascent.
